awd_titl_txt: CIVIC-PG Track A - Developing Community-Informed Strategies for Increased Longevity of Urban Trees to Mitigate Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to provide government, community, and financial support for long-term maintenance of a healthy tree canopy to mitigate air pollution and exacerbation of urban heat from climate change, especially in communities at greatest risk from increased heat as a result of disinvestment and racial discrimination. By developing tree maintenance plans that align with community values and sharing lessons learned across the Midwest region through a newly formed Midwest tree hub, this project will develop tools for tapping into non-traditional funds for tree maintenance that alleviate the effects of extreme heat while also improving air quality, reducing energy burdens, and addressing other community priorities. This project significantly adds to the work on expanding tree canopy to maximize benefits to human and environmental health. While many communities hold pieces of the puzzle, such as where trees should be planted and how to fund the planting of new trees, the ability to maintain a healthy tree canopy over time is often thwarted by a lack of resources, knowledge, and coordination. This project will focus on those barriers by leveraging support, sharing knowledge, and increasing coordination to equitably sustain healthy tree canopies to mitigate the effects of climate change.

This planning effort brings together clusters of local government, NGOs, and academic institutions in four Midwestern communities to build climate resilience by developing long-term, community-based solutions to maintain and expand tree canopy, focusing on communities that have experienced the most disinvestment and suffered the greatest disparities in health, income, and climate resilience. This work will bring together local government and community organizations in Indianapolis; Kansas City, Missouri; Dane County, Wisconsin; and St. Louis, to share successful tools, datasets, and strategies as well as dive deeper into common challenges and barriers that will not only benefit their communities but have impacts throughout the Midwest. The focus communities have been collecting data and exploring resources to better plan for expanded tree canopy in their respective locales. This multi-city and multi-institution collaboration will expand partner and stakeholder knowledge in: quantifying benefits of planting and maintenance strategies as planting zones shift due to climate change, best practices for the deployment of sensors and technology to aid in more efficient and effective tree maintenance, community engagement strategies for developing and implementing long-term maintenance plans prioritizing underserved and historically disinvested areas, and the possibility of using carbon credits as long-term funding for local tree programs. 

This project is in response to the Civic Innovation Challenge program—Track A. Living in a changing climate: pre-disaster action around adaptation, resilience, and mitigation—and is a collaboration between NSF, the Department of Homeland Security, and the Department of Energy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2022, twenty organizations across the higher education, local government, business, and nonprofit sectors formed the Midwest Climate Collaborative (MCC). In one year, that number grew to over 60, and through an NSF CIVIC Phase 1 grant several MCC members came together to better understand what makes local efforts to expand urban tree canopy successful for building climate resilience. Twelve partners across four communities in the Midwest met regularly to discuss strategies, best practices, and common challenges to the long-term maintenance of trees. In each community of Dane County, WI; Indianapolis, IN; Kansas City, MO; and St. Louis, MO, the MCC convened partners from academic research institutions, local governments, and nonprofits. These meetings produced a greater understanding of the unique challenges in the Midwest region as they provided an opportunity for the research community to hear directly from the people and organizations responsible for planting, pruning, and maintaining trees in public rights of way. 

While much effort has been placed on the importance of planting trees in order to mitigate the urban heat island effect, this group exposed many of the more complicated challenges of setting trees up to thrive, such as placement in dense, urban areas and selecting species that will survive strong winds, drought, and flooding, which are all increasing in light of climate change. Additionally, the group explored how to keep trees healthy once they are in the ground by engaging the community in their acceptance and long-term care. These cross-sector conversations between multiple communities are not common given the limited capacity of local governments and nonprofits, the ones responsible for planting and maintaining trees, to engage with and implement the latest research. The hurdles to applying best practices because of how local governments are structured and funded, plus the community?s concerns about the expense and liability of trees, especially in under-resourced neighborhoods, were highlighted extensively because of this grant.  

Ultimately, the grant partners identified five focus areas for urban forestry programs to be successful in using trees to build climate resilience:  1) community engagement, 2) data collection and analysis regarding canopy cover and climate vulnerability, 3) planting and maintenance strategies, 4) policy changes, and 5) resources, such as funding, labor, and inventory. By looking specifically at the expansion of tree canopy in the most climate vulnerable neighborhoods, the partners agreed that all efforts must start with community engagement because without a deep understanding of a community?s values, priorities, and local knowledge, the other components will miss the mark. Because trees require care over time in order to provide benefits back to the community in the form of shade, air quality, water absorption, and CO2 sequestration, residents are critical to any program?s success. Feedback from the local government and community partners also revealed several data gaps. Cities across the region are working with a hodgepodge of maps and datasets, all trying to discern who is most vulnerable and what solutions will garner the greatest benefits. Through this grant, partners were able to learn what resources their colleagues across the region are relying on. This process also surfaced the need for a systematic approach to collecting and analyzing data that reflects the latest science and community values.

To support urban forestry efforts in the region this grant produced a new resource, the Midwest Tree Canopy Hub, for practitioners and researchers to share strategies and tools that are working in Midwestern communities. This hub will continue to grow with resources so that urban forestry programs can learn from one another about how they are adapting to changing weather patterns, how they are utilizing tree canopy and air quality monitoring data, and how to best respond to community concerns about heat and trees.
